question.title: (array & string) Difference in Java vs. C

node.contents: Could you be more specific? "Tell me how string and arrays work in Java" is too broad.

astNode.text: Could you be more specific? "Tell me how string and arrays work in Java" is too broad.

node.contents: I know about C and I am entering into Java and confused about its approach towards Array and String. Its totally different from array and string in C. Please help me understand what actually the difference between C and Java (for string and array).

astNode.text: I know about C and I am entering into Java and confused about its approach towards Array and String. Its totally different from array and string in C. Please help me understand what actually the difference between C and Java (for string and array).

node.contents:
If you really need to know the difference you need to know the diff between ptr in C and ref in java
when you say in C: char str[10]; ==> you allocate a sequence 10 blocks in memory and every block's size is sizeof(char) and terminated by null so you can deal with strings with normal ptr operations.

node.contents: java: when you say String str; ==> you create an object java.lang.String which inherit some methods which in the java.lang.String Class like compare(),equals(),contains(),charAt() and more.

node.contents: I would not use `new String("some value")` but rather `"some value"` directly.

node.contents: In Java, you can declare either `int[] a`, or `int a[]`. Both are completely interchangeable.

astNode.text: In Java, you can declare either `int[] a`, or `int a[]`. Both are completely interchangeable.

node.contents: Very complete. Except: Java also supports the old C array declaration style of putting the brackets on the variable name. It is, however, considered bad style.

node.contents: Arrays:

astNode.text: Arrays:

node.contents: The first obvious difference is that Java doesn't use the same declaration syntax for arrays as C. In C, the array subscript is part of the declarator, whereas in Java it's part of the type specification:

astNode.text: The first obvious difference is that Java doesn't use the same declaration syntax for arrays as C. In C, the array subscript is part of the declarator, whereas in Java it's part of the type specification:

elements.contents: int[] arr; // Java, arr is null until array object is instantiated int arr[]; // C, incomplete declaration

fragments.text: int[] arr; // Java, arr is null until array object is instantiated int arr[]; // C, incomplete declaration

units.rawText: int[] arr; // Java, arr is null until array object is instantiated int arr[]; // C, incomplete declaration

node.contents: Note that, in Java, arr exists but is null-valued. In C, arr doesn't exist until a complete declaration appears.

astNode.text: Note that, in Java, arr exists but is null-valued. In C, arr doesn't exist until a complete declaration appears.

elements.contents: int[][] 2Darr; // Java, arr is null until array object is instantiated int 2Darr[][]; // Illegal declaration in C; size must be specified for at least // the outer dimension

fragments.text: int[][] 2Darr; // Java, arr is null until array object is instantiated int 2Darr[][]; // Illegal declaration in C; size must be specified for at least // the outer dimension

units.rawText: int[][] 2Darr; // Java, arr is null until array object is instantiated int 2Darr[][]; // Illegal declaration in C; size must be specified for at least // the outer dimension

node.contents: Array objects in Java must be instantiated with a new operation, and it's there that the array size is specified:

astNode.text: Array objects in Java must be instantiated with a new operation, and it's there that the array size is specified:

elements.contents: int[] arr = new int [10]; int[][] 2Darr = new int[10][20];

units.rawText: int[] arr = new int [10]; int[][] 2Darr = new int[10][20];

node.contents: If the array is not of a primitive type, each individual array element must be separately instantiated:

astNode.text: If the array is not of a primitive type, each individual array element must be separately instantiated:

elements.contents: String[] strs = new String[10]; for (int i = 0; i < strs.length; i++) strs[i] = new String("some value");

units.rawText: String[] strs = new String[10]; for (int i = 0; i < strs.length; i++) strs[i] = new String("some value");

node.contents: Array expressions in Java do not have their types "decay" to pointer types like array expressions in C (which is handy, since Java doesn't have pointer types per se); array types in Java are "first class" objects, meaning they retain all their type characteristics in any context. When you pass an array object to a method, the method receives an array object, not a pointer.

astNode.text: Array expressions in Java do not have their types "decay" to pointer types like array expressions in C (which is handy, since Java doesn't have pointer types per se); array types in Java are "first class" objects, meaning they retain all their type characteristics in any context. When you pass an array object to a method, the method receives an array object, not a pointer.

node.contents: Java arrays know how big they are (given by the .length attribute).

astNode.text: Java arrays know how big they are (given by the .length attribute).

node.contents: Strings:

astNode.text: Strings:

node.contents: Unlike C, Java supplies a distinct String data type. Do not think of Java strings as 0-terminated arrays of char; they are something different.

astNode.text: Unlike C, Java supplies a distinct String data type. Do not think of Java strings as 0-terminated arrays of char; they are something different.

node.contents: Java String objects are immutable; you cannot modify the contents of a String object. You can create a new String object from the modified contents of an existing String object. There are also classes like StringBuilder and StringBuffer that allow you to manipulate character data directly and create new String objects.

astNode.text: Java String objects are immutable; you cannot modify the contents of a String object. You can create a new String object from the modified contents of an existing String object. There are also classes like StringBuilder and StringBuffer that allow you to manipulate character data directly and create new String objects.

node.contents: using '==' operator in java to compare Strings doesn't grantee to be correct because this operator when deal with Objects it compares only the references of the object. to compare use .equals() = strcmp() in C +Java doesn't support operator overloading like C++ to overload the == operator but you can to override the method .equals() if you want.

astNode.text: using '==' operator in java to compare Strings doesn't grantee to be correct because this operator when deal with Objects it compares only the references of the object. to compare use .equals() = strcmp() in C +Java doesn't support operator overloading like C++ to overload the == operator but you can to override the method .equals() if you want.

node.contents: The `==` operator tests for identity, not equalness. In order to test for equalness, use the `equals` method. This is valid not only for Strings, but for all Objects.

astNode.text: The `==` operator tests for identity, not equalness. In order to test for equalness, use the `equals` method. This is valid not only for Strings, but for all Objects.

node.contents: In C string is indeed array of character ended by '\0'. In Java string is a class. The java string can better be compared with std::string in C++ rather than C character array.

astNode.text: In C string is indeed array of character ended by '\0'. In Java string is a class. The java string can better be compared with std::string in C++ rather than C character array.

node.contents: Arrays

astNode.text: Arrays

node.contents: Arrays in C are simply syntactic sugar to access contiguous memory spaces, or - vulgarizing it shamelessly here - a variant of a pointer notation. To avoid allocating big chunks of contiguous memory and avoid having to reallocate your memory yourself manipulating data of variable size, you then resort to implementations of common Computer Science Data Structure concepts (for instance, a linked list, which uses a pointer to indicate the memory address of the next element in a series).

astNode.text: Arrays in C are simply syntactic sugar to access contiguous memory spaces, or - vulgarizing it shamelessly here - a variant of a pointer notation. To avoid allocating big chunks of contiguous memory and avoid having to reallocate your memory yourself manipulating data of variable size, you then resort to implementations of common Computer Science Data Structure concepts (for instance, a linked list, which uses a pointer to indicate the memory address of the next element in a series).

node.contents: You can substitute pointer arithmetic with array notations in C, and vice versa.

astNode.text: You can substitute pointer arithmetic with array notations in C, and vice versa.

node.contents: The following will print the 5 elements of an array using different access methods:

astNode.text: The following will print the 5 elements of an array using different access methods:

elements.contents: #include <stdio.h> int main(int ac, char **av) { char arr[2] = {'a', 'b'}; printf("0:%c 0:%c 1:%c 1:%c\n", arr[0], *arr, arr[1], *(arr + 1)); return (0); }

fragments.text: int main(int ac, char **av) { char arr[2] = {'a', 'b'}; printf("0:%c 0:%c 1:%c 1:%c\n", arr[0], *arr, arr[1], *(arr + 1));

node.contents: Strings

astNode.text: Strings

node.contents: Here I assume you want to know about the conventional C-string implementation, and not one provided by a 3rd-party library.

astNode.text: Here I assume you want to know about the conventional C-string implementation, and not one provided by a 3rd-party library.

node.contents: Strings in C are basically simply arrays of characters. The main reason for this is obvious: as you need to often manipulate strings and print them to a stream, using a contiguous memory space makes sense and is an easy implementation. However, as you need to remember the size of your contiguous memory space to not inadvertently access something forbidden, we rely on the concept of a "NULL-terminated string", meaning a string of N characters is a actually an array of N + 1 characters terminated by a trailing '\0' character, which is used as the de-facto character to look for when you want to reach the end of a string.

astNode.text: Strings in C are basically simply arrays of characters. The main reason for this is obvious: as you need to often manipulate strings and print them to a stream, using a contiguous memory space makes sense and is an easy implementation. However, as you need to remember the size of your contiguous memory space to not inadvertently access something forbidden, we rely on the concept of a "NULL-terminated string", meaning a string of N characters is a actually an array of N + 1 characters terminated by a trailing '\0' character, which is used as the de-facto character to look for when you want to reach the end of a string.

node.contents: Where strdup() is a function of the C standard library allocating memory for your string and injecting the characters in there. Or you can allocate memory yourself with malloc() and copy characters manually or with a function like strcpy().

astNode.text: Where strdup() is a function of the C standard library allocating memory for your string and injecting the characters in there. Or you can allocate memory yourself with malloc() and copy characters manually or with a function like strcpy().

node.contents: This particular declaration is thus mutable, and your are free to modify the content of the string (which in the end is just a dynamically allocated array of characters, allocated with malloc()).

astNode.text: This particular declaration is thus mutable, and your are free to modify the content of the string (which in the end is just a dynamically allocated array of characters, allocated with malloc()).

node.contents: If you need to change the length of this string (add/remove characters to/from it), you will need to everytime be wary of the allocated memory. For instance, calling strcat() will fail if you haven't reallocated some additional memory first. Some functions, however, will take care of this for you.

astNode.text: If you need to change the length of this string (add/remove characters to/from it), you will need to everytime be wary of the allocated memory. For instance, calling strcat() will fail if you haven't reallocated some additional memory first. Some functions, however, will take care of this for you.

node.contents: The C string does NOT support Unicode by default. You need to implement to manage code points yourself, or consider using 3rd-party library.

astNode.text: The C string does NOT support Unicode by default. You need to implement to manage code points yourself, or consider using 3rd-party library.

node.contents: In Java

node.contents: Arrays

astNode.text: Arrays

node.contents: Arrays in Java are very close to their C parent (to the point that we even have a method for efficient array-to-array-copy support using a bare-bone native implementation: System.arraycopy()). They represent contiguous memory spaces.

astNode.text: Arrays in Java are very close to their C parent (to the point that we even have a method for efficient array-to-array-copy support using a bare-bone native implementation: System.arraycopy()). They represent contiguous memory spaces.

node.contents: However, they wrap these bare-bone arrays within an object (which keeps track of the size/length of the array for you).

astNode.text: However, they wrap these bare-bone arrays within an object (which keeps track of the size/length of the array for you).

node.contents: Java arrays can have their content modified, but like their C counterpart, you will need to allocate more memory when trying to expand them (except you do it indirectly, and will usually reallocate a complete array instead of doing a realloc() like in C).

astNode.text: Java arrays can have their content modified, but like their C counterpart, you will need to allocate more memory when trying to expand them (except you do it indirectly, and will usually reallocate a complete array instead of doing a realloc() like in C).

node.contents: Strings

astNode.text: Strings

node.contents: Strings in Java are immutable, meaning they cannot be changed, once initialized, and operations on String actually create new String instances. Look up StringBuilder and StringBuffer for efficient string manipulation with an existing instance, and beware of their internal implementation details (especially when it comes to pre-setting the capacity of your buffer efficiently, to avoid frequent re-allocations).

astNode.text: Strings in Java are immutable, meaning they cannot be changed, once initialized, and operations on String actually create new String instances. Look up StringBuilder and StringBuffer for efficient string manipulation with an existing instance, and beware of their internal implementation details (especially when it comes to pre-setting the capacity of your buffer efficiently, to avoid frequent re-allocations).

node.contents: In the underlying implementation, the Java String* classes also use an arrays of characters, like their C parent.

astNode.text: In the underlying implementation, the Java String* classes also use an arrays of characters, like their C parent.

node.contents: This implies that they use more memory than the bare-bone C implementation, as you have the overhead of your instance.

astNode.text: This implies that they use more memory than the bare-bone C implementation, as you have the overhead of your instance.

node.contents: Not only that, they actually use a lot more memory because the Java String class provides Unicode support by default, meaning it allows for multiple code points per character (which is not a trivial thing to do in C, in comparison).

astNode.text: Not only that, they actually use a lot more memory because the Java String class provides Unicode support by default, meaning it allows for multiple code points per character (which is not a trivial thing to do in C, in comparison).

node.contents: On the other, notice that except if considering performance, you don't need to worry about threading, memory, and implementing functions looking for trailing '\0' characters.

astNode.text: On the other, notice that except if considering performance, you don't need to worry about threading, memory, and implementing functions looking for trailing '\0' characters.

node.contents: And, very important, in Java Strings are immutable. If you want to change a String slightly, you can only create a new String (e.g. using a StringBuilder, or as a C-programmer, use String.format())

astNode.text: And, very important, in Java Strings are immutable. If you want to change a String slightly, you can only create a new String (e.g. using a StringBuilder, or as a C-programmer, use String.format())

node.contents: In C, a string is typically just an array of (or a pointer to) chars, terminated with a NUL (\0) character. You can process a string as you would process any array.

astNode.text: In C, a string is typically just an array of (or a pointer to) chars, terminated with a NUL (\0) character. You can process a string as you would process any array.

node.contents: In Java, however, strings are not arrays. Java strings are instances (objects) of the java.lang.String class. They represent character data, but the internal implementation is not exposed to the programmer. You cannot treat them as arrays, although, if required, you can extract string data as an array of bytes or chars (methods getBytes and getChars). Note also that Java chars are 16-bits, always, while chars in C are typically (not always) 8-bit.

astNode.text: In Java, however, strings are not arrays. Java strings are instances (objects) of the java.lang.String class. They represent character data, but the internal implementation is not exposed to the programmer. You cannot treat them as arrays, although, if required, you can extract string data as an array of bytes or chars (methods getBytes and getChars). Note also that Java chars are 16-bits, always, while chars in C are typically (not always) 8-bit.

node.contents: To tell the size of a C "string", you have to pass a pointer to a separate function. You could argue that there are no strings in C at all, just conventions for arrays of char.

node.contents: Java, on the other hand, has strings built in as a part of the language itself. The Java String has methods, which can tell you its size for instance. Java has primitive types, like C: float and int.
